Furnas]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1894|07|30|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Van Buren, Arkansas]], USA | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1959|05|08|1894|07|30}} | death_place = Washington, D.C., USA | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] }} '''Donald Aubrey Quarles''' (July 30, 1894 - May 8, 1959) was a [[Telecommunications engineering|communications engineer]], senior level executive with [[Bell Telephone Laboratories]] and [[Western Electric]], and a top official in the [[United States Department of Defense]] during the [[Eisenhower Administration]]. He served as both [[Secretary of the Air Force]] and [[Deputy Secretary of Defense]].
==Early years== He was born on July 30, 1894 in [[Van Buren, Arkansas]].
Quarles graduated from Van Buren High School in 1910 at age of 15. He taught [[mathematics]] in Van Buren High School, and attended summer school at [[University of Missouri]] until he was accepted into [[Yale University]] in 1912. He graduated from Yale with a bachelor of arts degree in 1916.<ref name="USAF">United States Air Force senior executive biography, [http://www.af.mil/bios/bio.asp?bioID=6830 "Donald A. Quarles"], ''Air Force Link'', Air Force History Support Office, Washington, D.C., February 14, 2008.</ref><ref name="AFHO">United States Air Force, [http://www.af.mil/history/person.asp?dec=&pid=123006469 "Donald A. Quarles"], ''Air Force Link'', Air Force History Office, Washington, D.C., February 14, 2008.</ref>
In May 1917, Quarles enlisted in the [[United States Army]] for service during World War I. He was a member of the [[42nd Infantry Division (United States)|42nd Infantry Division]] (better known as the "[[Rainbow Division]]"). As an artillery officer, Quarles attained the rank of [[Captain (United States)|captain]] and served in France and Germany for two years.<ref name="USAF"/><ref name="AFHO"/>
==Laboratory engineer== After the war, Quarles went to work at [[Western Electric|Western Electric Company]]. During this time, he also studied [[theoretical physics]] at [[Columbia University]] on a part-time basis. In 1925, he joined [[Bell Labs|Bell Telephone Labs]] in [[Murray Hill, New Jersey]]. Through the 1930s and early 1940s, Quarles continued to advance within the Bell Labs organization.<ref name="USAF"/>
In 1940, he was selected as director of the Transmission Development Department which concentrated on military electronic systems, particularly [[radar]] development. He became director of Bell’s Apparatus Development in 1946. He was elected [[Mayor of Englewood, New Jersey]] in 1946 to 1948.<ref name=ieee/><ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=D. A. Quarles |url=http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/images/3/35/Quarles_-_da_quarles_named_sandia_president.pdf |quote=... He was previously a resident and at one time, mayor of Englewood, New Jersey. |newspaper=[[Bell Laboratories Record]] |date=March 1, 1952 |accessdate=2011-10-31 }}</ref> He then was vice president of Bell Telephone Laboratories in 1948. During this time, he was appointed to the new Committee on Electronics within the Department of Defense’s Joint Research and Development Board, becoming chairman of the Committee on Electronics in 1949. In March 1952, Quarles became vice president of Western Electric and president of [[Sandia Corporation]]. Sandia was a subsidiary company of Western Electric responsible for operating the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]]’s [[Sandia National Laboratory]] in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]], New Mexico.<ref name="USAF"/> Quarles was president of the [[American Institute of Electrical Engineers]] from 1952 to 1953.<ref name=ieee>{{cite web |url=http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Donald_A._Quarles |title=Donald A. Quarles |work=IEEE Global History Network |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=August 9, 2011|quote=Active in civic affairs in Englewood, Mr. Quarles has served as a member and then president of the Common Council from 1940 to 1946, and as mayor from 1946 to 1948. ...}}</ref>
==Public service== In September 1953, President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] appointed Quarles Assistant Secretary of Defense for research and development. Subsequently, he was jointly selected by both the [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] and the [[United States Secretary of Commerce|Secretary of Commerce]] to be the chairman of the Air Navigation Development Board. In March 1954, President Eisenhower appointed Quarles to the [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics]].<ref name="AFHO"/>
On August 11, 1955, [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|President Eisenhower]] appointed Quarles as interim [[United States Secretary of the Air Force|Secretary of the Air Force]], and he was sworn into office August 15, 1955. The [[United States Senate]] confirmed his appointment on February 16, 1956. As Secretary, Quarles stressed the need to use cutting edge technology to maintain military superiority over the [[Soviet Union]]. He supported expanded funding for research and development programs, and pressed for rapid fielding of [[B-52 Stratofortress]], [[F-102 Delta Dagger]], and [[F-104 Starfighter]] aircraft.<ref name="USAF"/><ref name="AFHO"/>
He resigned as Secretary of the Air Force on April 30, 1957 to accept a new Presidential appointment as [[Deputy Secretary of Defense]]. He remained in that position until his sudden death from a heart attack in Washington, D.C., on May 8, 1959.<ref name="AFHO"/>
==Funeral== [[File:Donald A. Quarles funeral procession.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Donald Quarles' funeral procession at Arlington Cemetery]]Quarles was given a special [[military funeral]] arranged by [[United States Army Military District of Washington|Military District of Washington]]. Beginning at noon on May 11, 1959, his casket lay in the Bethlehem Chapel at the [[Washington National Cathedral]] for twenty-four hours. The funeral service was held in the nave of the cathedral the next day. Following the service, a hearse carried his casket to the Memorial Gate at [[Arlington National Cemetery]] where the casket was transferred to a [[Caisson (military)|caisson]]. A military escort, consisting of one platoon each from the Army, [[United States Navy|Navy]], [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]], [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], and [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] lead the funeral procession to the grave site. Vice President [[Richard M. Nixon]] led the official party at public funeral service and Arlington procession, and President Eisenhower attended the graveside rites.<ref>[http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/donaldau.htm "Donald Aubrey Quarles, Captain, United States Army, Secretary of the Air Force, Deputy Secretary of Defense"], ''Arlington National Cemetery website'', March 19, 2006.</ref>
Among the many honors Quarles received during his career as an engineer and public official were honorary doctorate degrees in engineering from the [[University of Arkansas]] in 1953 and [[New York University]] in 1955. He received the [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]]{{clarify|this is a class within an award|date=September 2011}} from Italy and the [[La Cruz Peruana al Merito Aeonautico]] from [[Peru]] in 1956. In 1957, be received the [[Order of Aeronautical Merit (Brazil)|Order of Aeronautical Merit]] from [[Brazil]] and the [[Major General C.C. Williams Gold Medal]] from the [[American Ordnance Association]]. That year, he was also awarded the [[United States Air Force Exceptional Service Award]].
==Legacy== He was posthumously awarded the United States' [[Medal of Freedom]] in 1959.<ref name="AFHO"/><ref>[http://www.eisenhower.archives.gov/listofholdingshtml/listofholdingsQ/QUARLESDONALDAPapers195059.pdf "Quarles, Donald A., papers 1950–59"], Dwight D. Eisenhower Library, Abilene, Kansas, July 1975.</ref> In 1966, a mountain range in [[Antarctica]] was named after Quarles. The [[Quarles Range]] was named at the outset of the [[International Geophysical Year]] and organization of U.S. activity in Antarctica.<ref>{{cite gnis | type = antarid | id = 12238| name =Quarles Range| accessdate = 2012-01-24}}</ref>
